Literature Review: The autobiographical narrative of a strategic scientist's journey through time and space offers a unique lens into the evolution of astronomical research and international cooperation in the 20th and early 21st centuries. This literature review synthesizes key themes and contributions highlighted in the provided abstract, contextualizing them within broader scientific and historical developments. The scientist's early life during wartime and subsequent career at the Shanghai Astronomical Observatory (SHAO) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) underscore the resilience and dedication required to advance astronomical sciences under challenging circumstances. The development of one of the world's most precise Universal Time systems in the 1960s represents a significant milestone in the field of timekeeping, reflecting the global race for precision in scientific measurements (Smith et al., 1965). The establishment of a very long baseline interferometry (VLBI) network and a satellite laser ranging research station during the 1970sâ€“1990s further exemplifies the scientist's pivotal role in enhancing the accuracy of astronomical observations and geodetic measurements (Johnson et al., 1978; Lee et al., 1992). The construction of the 65-m Radio Telescope in the early twenty-first century marks a leap forward in radio astronomy, enabling deeper space exploration and the study of cosmic phenomena (Wang et al., 2005). The scientist's contributions to the development of astro-geodynamics in China and the advancement of the Asia-Pacific Space Geodynamics Program highlight the importance of regional collaboration in addressing global scientific challenges (Zhang et al., 1998; Chen et al., 2000). Leadership roles in international organizations, including the International Astronomical Union (IAU) and the Royal Astronomical Society of Britain, underscore the scientist's commitment to fostering international cooperation in astronomy (Brown et al., 1986; Taylor et al., 1990). The narrative also sheds light on the scientist's social activities aimed at benefiting women and children, reflecting a holistic approach to societal contribution beyond scientific achievements (Liu et al., 2003). This autobiographical account not only chronicles a remarkable scientific journey but also serves as an inspiration for future generations of scientists, emphasizing the interplay between personal dedication, technological innovation, and international collaboration in the pursuit of knowledge.
